# Ellipsis in Stylistics
AI-enhanced description
The document discusses ellipsis as a cohesive device where missing items in speech or text require reader interpretation. It highlights examples from two texts, examining how ellipsis reflects character mood and style, while noting its common usage in speech versus potential incoherence in writing. The analysis indicates a deliberate use of ellipsis by authors to engage readers and involves a unique style where character differentiation is less pronounced.

The ellipses come here wholly within the speech of
one character ÀóÀóÀóÀóÀó where it represents his perturbance and
mood. Note that almost all of this ellipsis involves the
omission of auxiliary verbs and subject pronouns ÀóÀóÀóÀó
which suggests that it is ruleÀó governed in some way.
Subject pronouns and auxiliaries are deleted in spoken
English quite frequently, but this usage is particularly
associated with upperÀó middleÀó class spoken English. In
this text, it demonstrates both the hastiness of the character
Charles, and also his disinclination to engage with Edith
and Robert whilst he waits foe Sheila.

Will you [marry] or will you not [marry].

![Verdict
There are so much ellipsis in this passage that it borders on the incoherent. Amazingly, this
is the opening of a novel (the main ellipsis are numbered):
‚ÄòI will ask you (1) once more. It is the last time (2). Will you or will you not (3)?‚Äô
1. Not recoverable from context for several lines: ‚Äòto marry me‚Äô;
2. ‚ÄòI will ask you‚Äô;
3. Not recoverable for several lines: ‚Äòmarry me‚Äô;
4. Not recoverable for several lines: ‚Äòmarry you‚Äô;
5. ‚ÄòI will tell you‚Äô;
6. ‚Äòtime‚Äô.
Note that in this passage, as in John Wain, Hurry on Down, ellipsis is most frequent in
speech . Here though, two characters, rather than one are employing it, and the range
of things ellipted is much wider.
](https://image.slidesharecdn.com/stylisticspresentationellipsis-200625112412/75/Ellipsis-in-Stylistics-13-2048.jpg)
![Verdict (Continued)
Even though ellipsis is more common in actual speech than in writing, it is difficult to
imagine a real conversation using it this much, and in this way. Conversation is usually
much more wordy!
This highly ellipted style would seem to be a deliberate choice on the part of ComptonÀó
BurnettÀóÀóÀóÀó as will be confirmed by reading any of her other novels. The effect is to
involve the reader as much as possible in creating the meaning of the textÀóÀóÀó hence the use
of dialogue rather than omniscient narration, the high frequency of ellipsis, and even the
higher frequency of pronoun replacementÀóÀóÀóÀó another feature of cohesion which relies on
the reader to supply the referent. Note the pronouns in this section:
](https://image.slidesharecdn.com/stylisticspresentationellipsis-200625112412/75/Ellipsis-in-Stylistics-14-2048.jpg)
![Verdict (Continued)
well, this is a last occasion. It becomes one. It is what you choose.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd what you do. I think you will be happy. And I hope she will. That is where the
question lies.‚Äô
‚Äòif I marry her, she should be. I will do my part.‚Äô
‚Äòit will be easier than hers. I wonder if you know it.‚Äô
‚Äòhers cannot be what yours would be. I am helpless there.‚Äô
Particularly the shifting reference of it. Some readers will find this style alienating, as it
requires considerable effort to read; whilst other readers will relish the logical,
unflappable, pedantic trait of the speakers. One of the most unusual features of
ComptonÀó Burnett‚Äôs writing is that she does not attempt to differentiate between her
characters in terms of their spoken styles. Usually, authors try to create caracters with
identifiable personalities through slight differences in their idiolects.
In ComptonÀó Burnett‚Äôs writing, however, characterization is subordinated
](https://image.slidesharecdn.com/stylisticspresentationellipsis-200625112412/75/Ellipsis-in-Stylistics-15-2048.jpg)
![Verdict (Continued)
to a fascination with logic; and, delightfully, all the characters speak in this
way, from the lord and lady of the manor to the children and the servants.
When considering the writing of Raymond Chandler, we remarked that this
distinctive stylistic trait was his terse handling of the verb phrase; ComptonÀó
Burnett‚Äôs style lies in her manipulation of ellipsis.
](https://image.slidesharecdn.com/stylisticspresentationellipsis-200625112412/75/Ellipsis-in-Stylistics-16-2048.jpg)

## Ellipsis in Stylistics
-   1.
    [Topic: ELLIPSIS Presented By:](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#1)Group 3
-   2.
    [Group Members ‚Ä¢ Ghaza Ejaz ‚Ä¢](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#2)Fatima Bint e Mazhar ‚Ä¢ Zarmeen Umer Write Up Done By ‚Ä¢ Zia Ur Rehman ‚Ä¢ Raiha Haider Presentation:
-   3.
    [Definition: ÔÇß Ellipses is](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#3)a cohesive device involving the absence of an item which the reader or listener must supply. The cohesive link is set up by the process of referring to recover the missing item (as in pronominal reference): How was Spain? I didn‚Äôt go ÀçÀçÀçÀçÀç (where ‚Äúto Spain‚Äù is ellipted). ÔÇß Ellipses can also be used to set up coherent links. ÔÇß Ellipsis is common in speech as a device for economy, but it‚Äôs use in writing treads a fine line between economy and incoherence (where too little information undermines understanding).
-   4.
    [Sources of the Absent Words](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#4)or Phrases While there is a cohesive link, the information comes from actual text or context of the text. However, a coherent link can also be formed where the absent phrase or word resides in common sense or general knowledge.
-   5.
    [TASK: Note the ellipses](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#5)in text 1 & 2. To what extent are they a product of the type of language being represented, and to what extent do they constitute a deliberate stylistic effort by the writer?
-   6.
    [TEXT 1 (The](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#6)Analyzed Part) ‚ÄòSheila isn‚Äôt here,‚Äô he said without waiting for Charles to say anything, and without any greeting. ‚ÄòDo You Mind if I come in all the same? I have Come some distance,‚Äô muttered Charles. ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs only Edith and me here,‚Äô said Robert, as if warning Charles that by coming in he was exposing himself to an unpleasant ordeal; which was true. Without answering, Charles levered himself past Robert and went into the hall. Edith came out of the kitchen and confronted him. ‚ÄòSheila isn‚Äôt here,‚Äô she said. ‚ÄòI Know,‚Äô said Charles, speaking too quickly to be fully intelligible. ‚ÄòRobert told me about it. Do you mind if come in perhaps I could have a cup of tea? Or tell me when Sheila will be back, I wanted to see her if I could.‚Äô Attribution: Text 2 John Wain, Hurry on Down, pp. 15Àó 16.
-   7.
    [Solution ‚Äò\[Do you\] Mind](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#7)if I come in all the same? \[I have\] Come some distance,‚Äô muttered Charles. ‚Äò\[I\] Know,‚Äô said Charles, speaking too quickly to be fully intelligible. ‚ÄòRobert told me \[she wasn‚Äôt here\]. \[Do you\] mind if \[I\] come in perhaps \[I could have a\] cup of tea? Or \[Could you tell me\] when Sheila \[will\] be back \[I\] wanted to see her if I could.‚Äô
-   8.
    [Verdict The ellipses come](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#8)here wholly within the speech of one character ÀóÀóÀóÀóÀó where it represents his perturbance and mood. Note that almost all of this ellipsis involves the omission of auxiliary verbs and subject pronouns ÀóÀóÀóÀó which suggests that it is ruleÀó governed in some way. Subject pronouns and auxiliaries are deleted in spoken English quite frequently, but this usage is particularly associated with upperÀó middleÀó class spoken English. In this text, it demonstrates both the hastiness of the character Charles, and also his disinclination to engage with Edith and Robert whilst he waits foe Sheila.
-   9.
    [TEXT 2 ‚ÄòI will](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#9)ask you once more. It is the last time. Will you or will you not?‚Äô ‚ÄòI will not. It is also the last time. It must be the last.‚Äô ‚Äòyou will not give me your reasons?‚Äô ‚ÄòI will give you one. You have too much. Your house and your land. Your parents and your sister. Your sister who is also your friend. Your work and your growing name. I like things to be on a moderate scale. To have them in my hands and not be held by them.‚Äô ‚Äòthis is not the only reason. There must be a deeper one.‚Äô ‚ÄòThere is. And it may be deep. I do not want to marry. I seldom say so, to be disbelieved.‚Äô You don‚Äôt feel that marriage would mean a fuller life? ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt want the things it would be full of. Light words are sometimes true.‚Äô ‚ÄòThen there must be a change. I do want to marry. I want to have descendants. I want to hand down my name. I could not keep up our relation under a wife‚Äôs eyes. It has escaped my parents.‚Äô ‚Äòyour father I daresay. What about your mother?‚Äô ‚ÄòI am not sure. It is hard to know.‚Äô ‚Äòit has not escaped her, or you would know. Silence has its use.‚Äô
-   10.
    [The speaker‚Äôs indifference](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#10)to convention appeared in her clothes, her cottage, and her habit of looking full at her companion and voicing her thought. She was a short, fair woman of about thirty, with a deep voice, a strongly cut face, and calm eyes that were said to see more than other people‚Äôs, and sometimes did. Her companion was a large, dark man, with solid, shapely features, heavy, gentle, nervous hands, strong, sudden movements and a look of smouldering force. He ignored convention in another way, and in one that was his own. A consciousness of being a known and regarded figured showed in his dress and his bearing, and was almost disguised. The breach of family tradition involved in his leading a writer‚Äôs life in addition to a landowner's, enhanced him in his own eyes and supported his conception of himself. ‚Äòwell, this is a last occasion. It becomes one. It is what you choose.‚Äô ‚ÄòAnd what you do. I think you will be happy. And I hope she will. That is where the question lies.‚Äô ‚Äòif I marry her, she should be. I will do my part.‚Äô ‚Äòit will be easier than hers. I wonder if you know it.‚Äô
-   11.
    [‚Äòhers cannot be](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#11)what yours would be. I am helpless there.‚Äô ‚Äòso am I. I am not fitted for ordinary domestic life.‚Äô ‚Äòso I must live with someone who is. And I shall not see the life as ordinary. None is so to me.‚Äô ‚ÄòHow do you see your own life? It is even less so to you?‚Äô ‚Äòit is as it is. As I am what I am. I know I am a man of full nature. I know I am built on a large scale. I am not afraid to say it.‚Äô ‚Äòit is true that most people would be. If I thought it of myself, I should. So you can‚Äôt know if I think it. But do you know anyone who thinks he is built on a small scale?‚Äô ‚ÄòI know many people who are. It is part of their interest to me.‚Äô ‚Äòbut not of their interest to themselves. Do they know on what scale they are?; ‚ÄòI am to marry someone who is on a moderate one, and who knows it.‚Äô ‚Äòthen I guess who it is. There is someone of whom it is true. And there would not be anyone else.‚Äô ‚Äòmy father perhaps?‚Äô ‚ÄòBut you can hardly marry him, Hereward.‚Äô Attribution: Ivy ComptonÀó Burnett, A God and His Gifts, pp. 5Àó7
-   12.
    [Solution ‚Ä¢ I will](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#12)only mention a few random here. Will you \[marry\] or will you not \[marry\]. I will not \[marry\]. There is \[another reason\].‚Äô \[It has escaped\] your father I daresay. ‚ÄòIf I marry her, she should be \[happy\]
-   13.
    [Verdict There are so](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#13)much ellipsis in this passage that it borders on the incoherent. Amazingly, this is the opening of a novel (the main ellipsis are numbered): ‚ÄòI will ask you (1) once more. It is the last time (2). Will you or will you not (3)?‚Äô 1. Not recoverable from context for several lines: ‚Äòto marry me‚Äô; 2. ‚ÄòI will ask you‚Äô; 3. Not recoverable for several lines: ‚Äòmarry me‚Äô; 4. Not recoverable for several lines: ‚Äòmarry you‚Äô; 5. ‚ÄòI will tell you‚Äô; 6. ‚Äòtime‚Äô. Note that in this passage, as in John Wain, Hurry on Down, ellipsis is most frequent in speech . Here though, two characters, rather than one are employing it, and the range of things ellipted is much wider.
-   14.
    [Verdict (Continued) Even though](https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ellipsis-in-stylistics/236202072#14)ellipsis is more common in actual speech than in writing, it is difficult to imagine a real conversation using it this much, and in this way. Conversation is usually much more wordy! This highly ellipted style would seem to be a deliberate choice on the part of ComptonÀó BurnettÀóÀóÀóÀó as will be confirmed by reading any of her other novels.
